questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about Chronic transfusions with RBCs in patients with Thalassemia?

options.label: C
options.text: Often proves fatal by age 30 years

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stimulates excessive ineffective erythropoiesis Most of the complications in thalassemia are a consequence of chronic hemolytic anemia, chronic transfusion, and iron loading. To be effective, transfusions and iron chelation must be started early, be uninterrupted, and continue lifelong. These transfusions improve oxygen delivery, suppress the excessive ineffective erythropoiesis, and prolong life. The inevitable side effects, notably iron overload, if not checked often prove fatal by age 30 years either through ensuing Cardiomyopathy or Endocrinopathies.

questions.text: A patient presented to your OPD. He was found to be anemic with an iron profile showing normal serum iron, normal TIBC, increased transferrin saturation, and increased serum ferritin. RDW is normal. He is most likely to have:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thalassemia Beta – Thalassaemia Minor (Heterozygote) The course is very mild and often this anemia is detected only when a therapy for mild hypochromic anemia fails. Symptoms are minimal (usually asymptomatic) Mild anemia, with mild hypochromia but with marked microcytosis (MCV is markedly reduced but MCH is reduced mildly) Total iron binding capacity is normal while serum ferritin is increased. Serum iron, transferrin saturation, and RDW can be normal or increased. The smear shows some target cells, and punctate basophilia. Raised HbA2 up to 4 –6% (normal HbA2 1.5 to 3%) Family history with one parent having thalassemia minor.

Highyeild:

Laboratory findings in iron deficiency versus thalassemia minor Iron deficiency Thalassemia minor Hemoglobin Normal to low Normal to low MCV Normal to low (varies depending on severity, as low as 60 fL)* Low (often <75 fL) RDW High Low RBC count Low High Reticulocyte count Low Normal to slightly increased Blood smear Microcytosis, target cells Microcytosis, abundant target cells, teardrop cells Hemolysis labs Normal Usually normal Iron studies Low ferritin and TSAT Normal (or slightly increased) ferritin

questions.text: The test as shown in the image below is used as a screening tool in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beta thalassemia NESTROFT (Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test): This is used to assess the osmotic fragility of red cells at a single concentration of buffered saline (0.36% in a single tube) visually without a spectrophotometer. A positive NESTROFT indicates that all red cells in the tested sample have not undergone lysis in 0.36% buffered saline. These unlysed red cells result in the hazy appearance of the contents of the tube and render the line on the paper indistinct. Thus a positive NESTROFT indicates decreased red cell osmotic fragility and increased resistance to osmotic lysis. Diagnostic Features of Thalassemia Major: Profound hypochromic anemia, severe red cell dysplasia Absence or severe reduction of HbA. NESTROFT test – It is a screening test for the detection of thalassemia & common hemoglobinopathies. Raised HbF (Most characteristic feature) in Hb electrophoresis (most important Test) Family history shows both parents having thalassemia minor. Erythrocyte protoporphyrin levels are characteristically normal in Thalassemia. Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin is a useful screening test for microcytic hypochromic anemia. Free Erythrocyte protoporphyrin levels are increased in iron deficiency anemias, lead poisoning, sideroblastic anemia, and anemia of chronic disease . Erythrocyte protoporphyrin levels are normal in Thalassemias

questions.text: You are posted in a labor room as an intern where you assisted in the delivery of a 30-week stillborn baby. The baby was found to be severely anemic. Which of the following types of Haemoglobin tetramer would you find in this condition from the given image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gamma The given scenario is of Alpha thalassemia stillborn with hydrops fetalis due to severe anemia. Alpha thalassemias are caused by reductions in alpha globin chains. Reduced accumulation of α-globin leaves non-α-globins unpaired and unable to participate in the formation of functional hemoglobin tetramers. In the fetus, absent or reduced synthesis of α-globin allows unpaired γ-globin chains, which are usually part of the HbF tetramer, to form γ4 or Hb Bart’s . Hb Bart’s has a very high O2 affinity and does not unload O2 in tissues. Severe anemia in Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis is a result of absent normal hemoglobin and ineffective erythropoiesis. Mothers of infants with Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis have a history of stillbirth and develop preeclampsia, polyhydramnios, and antepartum hemorrhage and have difficult labor and delivery. Intrauterine transfusion of the fetus is possible.

Extraedge:

Since alpha globin chains are required for the synthesis of fetal hemoglobin (Hb F), manifestations of alpha thalassemia begin during the prenatal period. Urogenital anomalies are present in most males with Alpha Thalassemia Major. hypospadias is the most common , Other abnormalities are undescended testes, bifid scrotum, hydrocele, and micropenis. Neurodevelopmental delay. Maternal complication-Pregnancy with a fetus with hydrops fetalis can cause mirror syndrome, characterized by maternal edema, proteinuria, and hypertension.

questions.text: A 5-year young girl presented with episodes of vomiting and decreased intake of food. On examination, she was found to be icteric along with an enlarged spleen. Her Hemoglobin was 6.2 gm%. HPLC was done and specific tetramers of Haemoglobin were found. Which of the following findings would likely be seen in the peripheral smear?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A. The given clinical scenario above is that of HbH disease which has manifested with the findings of anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly. In the most common − −/−α genotype, mean hemoglobin in adults is ~11 g/dL with findings of hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thalassemia bone changes in the face, and growth impairment seen in 20–50% of cases, depending on underlying genotype. HbH inclusions can be induced in some red cells after incubation and staining with brilliant cresyl blue Red cells from a patient with acquired hemoglobin H disease were incubated in vitro with new methylene blue. Multiple ("golf ball-like") small inclusions due to the precipitation of hemoglobin H are seen as a result of interaction with this dye. The peripheral smear in HbH disease is due to the presence of tetramer of Beta chain, which is known as golf ball appearance on brilliant cresyl blue staining as given in image A. Transfusions are not usually needed in HbH disease. Nevertheless, depending on the genotype of the disease, transfusions might be necessary especially when anemia becomes more severe as in this girl above, and also with acute anemic episodes or pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B.- The image shows Heinz bodies present in G-6PD deficiency. Option: C.- The image shows Howell jolly bodies present in asplenia, sickle cell disease, megaloblastic anemia Option: D. - Image shows target cells that are present in thalassemia, but not characteristic of HbH disease.

Extraedge:

Alpha thalassemias here are four alpha globin genes (two genes at the alpha-globin locus inherited from each parent). Alpha thalassemia is caused by reduced production of alpha chains and accumulation of excess beta-like chains. Hemoglobin Barts – Hemoglobin Barts (Hb Barts) is a complete lack of alpha chains (--/--). Hemoglobin H disease – Hemoglobin H (Hb H) disease is the loss of three alpha chain genes (--/a-). Alpha thalassemia minor – Alpha thalassemia minor is a loss of two alpha chain genes (--/aa or -a/-a).

questions.text: An 8 year old girl came with the history that she is tired most of the time whilst playing, compared to other children of her age. She has on-and-off episodes of yellowish discoloration of her skin. On examination, she was found to have pallor, icterus, and palpable spleen. Investigations revealed Haemoglobin of 6.9gm% and P/S showed microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells. Which of the following will be LEAST present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemoglobinuria The given Factual scenario above depicts the child with clinical features suggestive of hemolytic anemia along with P/S showing hypochromic and microcytic anemia with target cells indicating that the patient is likely suffering from thalassemia. Features of hemolytic anemia in the form of hepatosplenomegaly, gallstones, and high-output cardiac failure due to severe anemia may be present. Leg ulcers are more found in thalassemia and more so common in Thalassemia intermedia Frontal bossing will be present due to extramedullary hematopoiesis giving a chipmunk facies appearance. The predominant cause of anemia is intramedullary destruction of erythroid precursors, known as ineffective erythropoiesis. Reduced deformability and phosphatidylserine exposure also cause extra- and intravascular hemolysis of those erythrocytes that gain entrance into the circulation. In poorly treated β thalassemia, severe anemia leads to bone marrow expansion and hepatosplenomegaly. Intravascular hemolysis is least seen in this, hence option C will be the answer to this question.

questions.text: A 5 year old child with a history of previous transfusion because of anemia presented to OPD with fever and features of iron overload like glucose intolerance, and cirrhosis. Which of the following is the chelating agent that can be used parenterally in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deferoxamine Patients with a history of repeated transfusion in early childhood point to likely diagnosis of Beta thalassemia major. Treatment for patients with features of iron overload will be iron chelating agents. As this patient's parenteral agent is asked, the answer will be deferoxamine. Desferroxamine is an excellent iron chelator, but it is not commonly chosen as the primary chelator because its requirement for continuous infusion often results in non-adherence.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - In thalassemia major, for treatment to be effective, transfusions and iron chelation must be started early, be uninterrupted, and continue lifelong. Older patients who did not have the advantage of effective chelation are more likely to develop multiple disease-related morbidities such as osteoporosis, endocrinopathies, liver disease, and renal failure. Two orally effective chelating agents are deferasirox and deferiprone. One intravenous chelator, deferoxamine, is available . BAL is used in case of lead or mercury poisoning and not iron overload.

Extraedge:

Side effects of Deferoxamine include visual and auditory neurotoxicity Deferoxamine is used treatment of aluminum-induced toxicity associated with chronic kidney disease. Transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia (previously beta thalassemia major) — Indications for initiating chelation therapy are listed below: After 10 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC), or greater than 100cc/Kg per year (PRBC hematocrit 60). Ferritin is greater than 1000ug/L. An magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver iron concentration >3mg/g/dry weight, or the cardiac T2* is less than 20 milliseconds [3,12,13].
